header.title: Why Jon Snow was right to say ‘white people’
header.postText: Channel 4 has expressed ‘regrets’ over news presenter Jon Snow saying he’d ‘never seen so many white people in one place’ at a pro-Brexit rally in Westminster. But should it be apologising?', 'Ofcom revealed there were over 2,000 complaints about the unscripted comment, which demonstrates an underlying issue of how uncomfortable white people can be about being called ‘white’.', 'This is perhaps largely because they are used to being the default definition of ‘people’. Everyone else, however, is labelled ‘BAME’, ‘POC’ and ‘non-white’. Those are the nice words.', '‘Whiteness’ has been scrutinised more in recent times than ever before in the UK and the majority, ‘host’ population had largely been able to live without thinking about race, which is a privilege in itself.', 'Saying ‘white people’ may be taken as an insult because it seems to generalise a large swathe of people.', 'Race and ethnicity lecturer at the University of Southampton Rima Saini explains: ‘White people have not, until relatively recently in this country, had their race used as a homogenising collective descriptive.', '‘This has coincided with a rise in discourse on racism, white privilege and power in all areas of society.', '‘The critique around the Jon Snow incident also reflects a growing backlash against this [conversation on race]. There is a sense that the racial majority [should] have legitimacy conferred on them by default, as the “indigenous” national population.', '‘But by referring to them as a collective and problematising their racial status, a lot of deep-seated emotions, whether resentment or vehement denial, about the very real racial inequalities that abound in the UK today are raised.’', 'So, in short, resistance to being called ‘white people’ is related to what ‘they’ feel is a legitimate claim to the land. Like how ‘Indian food’ in India is just called ‘food’, because it comes from there. In this way, it seems white people don’t need to be referred to as such, they belong. Everyone else is just a guest or an added extra.', 'Some felt Snow’s comments didn’t have any relevance to the pro-Brexit demonstration and had he said, ‘look at all these black people’, it would’ve been considered racially insensitive. But he was drawing attention to what he saw as the elephant in the room — the lack of ethnic minorities on the march. That’s good journalism.', 'Framing this as reverse racism against white people fails to acknowledge the power dynamics so key to the whole subject area.', 'Grouping white people – as ethnic minorities so often are – is necessary to see how ‘whiteness’ is complicit in racism.', 'Examining white people as the dominant majority and how they affect the lives of everyone else — and why this is a problem — seems to be perceived as a threat. Frankly, it is a threat to white people who want to retain the advantage they have built up over hundreds of years.', 'So, Jon Snow isn’t the enemy and neither are all white people. Ignorance is the enemy. And part of that ignorance is failing to see race.', 'Everyone is affected, it’s just a question of whether you recognise that. Then assess whether your racial background and make-up are working for or against you.', '‘White people’ reacting defensively to the issue is a clear example of white fragility on race issues and does nothing to further the conversation. Part of that conversation is being able to say ‘white people’.', 'We need to have an honest discourse to dismantle conscious and unconscious feelings of white supremacy.', 'Being white is something to be aware of, not ashamed of.

commentThread.commentText: Why can't we call a person what they are in truth? I am a white person, does that make me a non black person or because I am catholic/christian in my beliefs am I a non muslim? I have friends of many different nationalities and colour, I love them all dearly, past present and future. My life has been imeasurably enriched by their friendship but on thing really stands out to me. Not once have either they or I been ashamed, scared or insulted by any reference to our colour or race. I know people of various religions yet non have ever been reticent to discuss their religion be it Jewish, Rastafarian, protestant catholic or even Jedi as one friend claimed. It's only when those terms are used with malice that we should get angry and complain.
